dolphinsData.name: Long-Beaked Common Dolphin
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: The Long-beaked Common dolphin, as its name suggests, is one of the most abundant cetacean species found in the ocean.

physical_characteristics.location: Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans, warmer tropical and subtropical waters

additional_info.habitat: Shallow waters close to the shoreline
additional_info.behavior: Often seen in groups called pods
additional_info.abundance: The Long-beaked Common dolphin is the most abundant dolphin species on earth
additional_info.population: There are approximately 6 million Common Dolphins in the ocean

dolphinsData.name: Short-Beaked Common Dolphin
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: Short-beaked Common dolphins, making up the rest of the Common dolphin population, were once believed to be the same species as the Long-beaked Common dolphin but have since been established as their own.

physical_characteristics.distinguishing_features: Shorter beaks, distinct coloring, rounder heads and bodies

additional_info.habitat: Wide-ranging habitats, including open ocean and coastal areas
additional_info.behavior: Social animals that often leap and play in the wake of boats
additional_info.speed: The Short-Beaked Common Dolphin is the fastest dolphin species, reaching up to 37 mph
additional_info.lifespan: The Short-Beaked Common Dolphin lives between 35 and 40 years

dolphinsData.name: Bottlenose Dolphin
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: Although it may not be the most abundant dolphin species on earth, the bottlenose dolphin has made a name for itself as the go-to when someone thinks of a dolphin.

physical_characteristics.color: Mostly grey but can range on a spectrum to almost black when reaching their dorsal fins and nearly white on their belly
physical_characteristics.size: Varies, with a short thick beak

additional_info.habitat: Warmer tropical waters, often in harbors, bays, and estuaries
additional_info.behavior: Highly intelligent and often engage in complex social behaviors
additional_info.fact: Bottlenose dolphins are often used in aquariums and Hollywood productions thanks to their high intelligence
additional_info.intelligence: A bottlenose dolphin’s brain is larger than a humans

dolphinsData.name: Hector’s Dolphin
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: Hector’s dolphins are both the smallest and the rarest dolphin species in the world, reaching only 4 – 5 feet as adults.

physical_characteristics.coloration: White on the belly and gray on the upper body, with a gray streak running along the center body to cover the tail and a black band around the eye that extends to the flipper

additional_info.behavior: Social animals that often travel in small groups
additional_info.population: There are approximately only 7,000 Hector’s dolphins in the ocean
additional_info.name_origin: Named after a New Zealand scientist, Sir James Hector

dolphinsData.name: Atlantic Humpbacked Dolphin
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: The Atlantic Humpbacked dolphin is endemic to the Atlantic Ocean, where it can be found only in the tropical and subtropical waters of the West African coast, with its range spreading from Morocco to Angola.

physical_characteristics.habitat: Coastal regions less than 30 meters deep
physical_characteristics.coloration: Gray or white, with an iconic hump under their dorsal fin

additional_info.behavior: Often found in shallow coastal waters, including bays and estuaries
additional_info.communication: Their hump may play an important role in social recognition among individuals

dolphinsData.name: Orca
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: The Orca, also known as the Killer Whale, is the largest of the dolphin family, often reaching sizes up to 27 feet (8.2m) with a weight of 3 – 4 tons.

physical_characteristics.coloration: White underbelly with a shiny black back, a white patch above each eye, and a tall, triangular-shaped dorsal fin

additional_info.habitat: Wide-ranging habitats, from polar to tropical regions
additional_info.behavior: Highly social animals that live in complex family groups
additional_info.diet: Varies by region, including fish, seals, and other marine mammals
additional_info.unique_fact: The Orca is the largest species of dolphin

dolphinsData.name: Irrawaddy Dolphin
dolphinsData.interesting_fact: Found in the coastal areas of South and Southeast Asia, the Irrawaddy dolphin is another interesting dolphin species that brings its own unique touch.

physical_characteristics.size: Varies, gray-to-blue-gray, distinctly rounded head with no beak, short blunt dorsal fin

additional_info.habitat: Brackish water near coastlines, estuaries, and river mouths
additional_info.behavior: Capable of spending time in freshwater and saltwater habitats
additional_info.unique_anatomy: The Irrawaddy’s blow hole opens to the front, unlike other dolphins
additional_info.name_origin: The Irrawaddy dolphin gets its name from a subspecies that is found in the Irrawaddy river
